segments.text: Those two I would consider guidebooks.
For a book that I would identify as a narrative, that is, it's largely print with only a few illustrations, what are among the most successful and impressed books of that sort?
I think the most successful ones are

the most part are in our military history series okay and there's a good market and good demand for military history books and among those i think a dark and bloody ground by ed miller and doomed at the start by bill barch are two of the best sellers in military history
And they probably sold around 3,000 to 4,000 copies somewhere.
Now what about the Centennial History of A&M and the updated, how did they do?
The Pictorial History or the two-volume Centennial History?
Well, both of them.
How did the two of them do?
Well, the Centennial History, I think,
really sold very few copies.
I think a lot of those were free copies to administration and alumni.
The pictorial history did fairly well.
I think the first edition, I believe, just off the top of my head, sold about 16,000 copies.
And now we have the second edition, and I really don't know how it's done.
I haven't checked those numbers in a long time.
And the band book did well, didn't it?
Well, it did well enough to justify its publication, although we were somewhat disappointed in that.
We thought that every person who had ever been a member of the band and then a lot of the Corps people would want a copy of that book, but it didn't work out that way.
Can you think of any that you or other members of the staff know, books that we might have done that got away that somebody else did that turned out to be?
Oh, yeah, sure.
I try to block those, though.
No, but could you give them?
If they're really good books, you know, I hate to see them go.
But can you give an example of one that we might have done if we'd wanted to, but we
I can't think of anything specifically right at the moment.
I'll think for a second.
I was thinking of the fish that got away.
Yeah.
Nothing that was really
tremendous national literary interest that I would kick myself around the block if I lost, but there have been some books that I wish we had done that for one reason or another went to another press.
I want to ask you some questions about being the editor now of a manuscript.
A manuscript comes in
And do you do any background preparation before you start editing that manuscript?
Well... On the author or the topic?
Well, um...
It depends on what you mean by editing.
At which stage?
At the copy editing stage or acquisitions?
Take me through the whole process.
Okay, the first thing we get is a letter from the author suggesting that the author has this wonderful manuscript that he wants us to publish.
And we ask for a full proposal with the description of the book and the sample chapters and so on.
And we take a look at that.
And if that looks like something that we could or should do, then we'll ask to see the manuscript at that stage.
One of the problems with editing these days is that we're publishing so many books that it's almost impossible for the editor to read every one of the manuscripts that comes in.
I'd love to if I had the time, but I just can't physically do it.
So what we usually do is skim through as much of the manuscript as we can and see if it's well written.
You can usually get a sense of the quality of the style.
But we don't check technical details as to the author's research, the quality of the research at that point.
If it looks feasible, we'll send it out for review to specialists.
Do you normally get, for an author that's unknown to the press, do you normally get a chapter to look at first or the whole manuscript?
We ask for samples first.
If it's somebody we don't know, definitely we ask for a letter of proposal with sample chapters and an outline, a synopsis of the chapters.
In general, about what percentage of those a chapter will lead you all to encourage them to later send the whole manuscript?
One out of three?
One out of three or four.
Then you get the whole manuscript, send it out to how many readers?
We have to have at least two readers.
If both those readers' reports are positive,
We don't need to go to a third reader.
But if there's some controversy, conflict between the reader's reports, or if one of them is negative, then we may or may not go to a third reader.
Is that standard industry-wide?
Yes, it is.
And then if the reader's reports are positive, then we'll present the manuscript with our recommendation
and the reports and the author's response to the reports to the faculty committee.
And it's their decision whether we should publish the book or not.
But if we presented it to them right, if the reports are good, and if it obviously is a fit for our list, then they'll approve it generally.
Can you think in your 25 years of experience here of any time when you all went contrary to the preliminary reader's report being negative and you all continued?
Can you think of one that worked out well?
Oh yes, we do that all the time.
Is that right?
Oh yeah.
Many times you'll get a negative reader's report from one reader and you know that either that reader
missed something in the manuscript, or over-read something, misconstrued information, or maybe even has a personal lax to grind.
And so you go ahead and get the second report.
Really, only I'd say 25% of the time, maybe even less, do I reject a manuscript on the basis of the first reader's report.
I usually
In most cases, I'll go ahead and get the second report before I'll send the manuscript back.
Many times, when I do get a negative report initially like that, I'll go back and look at the manuscript myself.
And if I disagree with the report especially, then I'll get a second report.
Now you take then the reader's reports and your evaluation.
And the author's responses to them.
Right.
You take that to the press committee.
Right.
And what is the official title we give to the?
It's the Texas A&M University Press Faculty Advisory Committee.
And how important is that group?
Well, they are the group that decides on what is issued, what is published under the imprint of the press.
So they are the editorial final deciders.
It's their job to evaluate and debate the good and bad points brought out by the readers and to decide if we should publish the book or not.
How important has that committee been in the years here?
part of the press, really.

We have a large committee compared to other university presses, but we've always had people on the committee who, for the most part, were very interested in what we were doing, very interested in publishing.
And so they've always
taking a strong interest in making good decisions.
As you recall your 25 years here, who are some people on those committees that you would want to single out for appreciation?
Well, you for one.
You were the first chairman of the committee.
Thank you.
And some of the people on that, on the first committee, I didn't know very well because I wasn't working directly
with them in that period, I know that I can't remember some of the people.
I couldn't name all the people on the committee at that time.
And perhaps you could, but I don't remember them all.
I really didn't get involved with the committee until after you had gone on to El Paso.
And Clint Phillips then became the chairman, and really worked more closely with the committee under Clint's term.
And then more recently, Gentry Steele.
All right, and Gentry's been the chairman about how long?
Six, seven years, I think.
I think it was about six years.
And Clint were both deans of faculty.
Right.
Was there any reason why that was changed as far as you know?
We had a change of the dean of faculty about the time that Tom Rotell started here.
And I think that it was felt that it
It would be easier for us to work with somebody who had already been on the committee and knew the operations on the committee.
Because Bill Perry had not.
And the new dean of faculty coming in, I think, was someone completely new, had never been on the committee or worked with him before.
Bill Perry was a professor of math.
Right.
And Tom, it was set up that Tom and the press would report
to Bill Perry.
And so I think it was Bill's decision to put someone on as the committee chairman rather than himself.
All right, as far as you know, the press in reality down through the years has reported to whom administratively?
Well, initially it reported directly to the president.
Frank Wardlaw went straight to Jack Williams.
and then to Jarvis Miller, and then it was transferred to Frank Hubert, and then it went back to reporting directly to the President under Frank Vandiver.
And then at some point, I think under Rick Studer in the early 90s, the President then... Bill Mobley?
Mobley, Bill Mobley.
decided to to transfer it to another office because he didn't have the time for the personal contact.
And I think that on paper it was the
provost, but in fact the dean of faculties.
Well, it went to Dean Gage, and I think he was the provost.
I know Rick worked directly with Dean for a while, and then I think that then perhaps when Mary Miller came in, it went on to the dean of faculty.
As far as you at the working level were aware,
Did the administration respond appropriately when the press needed a response?
That is, did y'all ever, were y'all ever like, gee, we never get a response, we made a request?
Did it seem that the- Well, yeah, I think there were some times when we would
would prepare a report or a white paper or something and not hear from the administration.

There was a scare during Rick's tour when we were in Austin for a Western University presses meeting, regional meeting of the association, and Rick got a message that he should get back to College Station immediately to justify
the university's appropriation to the press.
So there were times when we felt that we were not
getting full attention or our message wasn't getting across to the administration.
Alright, while we're on this side road about away from editing, were you at the working level aware ever of a regent or a politician or a former student ever trying to interfere in a press decision?
Yes.
Can you give any examples?
There was a fellow from South Texas, I think he was an engineer, a retired Aggie, who had written some books and had contacted me and in fact had sent me a manuscript or two that I had reviewed.
He had sent back to him and told him that it really wasn't the kind of manuscript we were looking for and the quality we were looking for.
And although it was on a good topic, one of them was on the great wrenches of the American West.
Tremendous topic, would have been an excellent book, but we felt that he just hadn't put it together well enough.
And so...

went for a few months and then we got a letter from the president's office saying who is this this fellow and why is he so upset that the university press hasn't published his book and they sent a copy of his letter and it was in effect what kind of idiots do you have working over there they they don't support the former students and we
We support the university, and we don't get anything back, and they don't want to publish this good material by a former student.

And we did get the president's support on that, and he stood by us and said, well, you know, the university press has to make these hard decisions, and they decided against your project, and I'm sorry, and that's that.
But that wasn't that.
this fellow wrote the president again and said, well, if that's the case, you're not getting any of my money.
Apparently, he cut the university off because there must have been some money involved that he was planning to give the university.
Were you, by chance, the editor of Clady Williams' father's book?
No, I didn't work with that directly.
But I was here, of course, when it was published.
Do you remember all that story?
A little bit.
I knew sort of what was going on with that.
We wanted to publish it.
We knew it was important to the press that we publish it, and fortunately we were able to get Ernest Wallace
to edit the book and get it into a shape that it was publishable, and it turned out to be a very good book.
It was a good deal.
Frank Wardlow, I think, deserves a good deal of that credit, doesn't he, for being able to work that alone?
Yeah, I think Lloyd Lyman was mainly the
person who is directly involved in negotiating that.
All right, back to the work of editing a manuscript.
Then you get the manuscript now ready for you to edit it.
You mean after the committee's approved it for publication?
Yes, yes.
Well, generally, if the author has responded to the readers' reports and made any revisions that the readers suggest,

anything that comes up in the discussion of the committee and anything that we see as editors that we see needs to be done to it if the author does all that then we'll go ahead with it at that point so there's really no more editing that we do at that point and we turn it over to copy editing
And then let the copy editors worry about polishing it up.
All right.
Describe then what I, let's see, what phrase should I use for this first editing?
Just editing?
Well, it's developmental editing.
It's, like I say, not much editing involved, really.
It's just working with the authors and the readers and getting the author to make
revisions that the readers recommend from their point of view as specialists in the field and knowledgeable people.
Right, and the editor at that point does not read
other books on the same topic to see if this person, this manuscript, makes sense or anything?
That is, does this manuscript stand on its own feet?
Is that right?
Yeah, generally the readers are familiar with the literature in that particular.
Oh, no, no, I was meaning you as the.
Oh, the editor?
No.
Okay.
No, not necessarily.
It's generally in one of the topic areas that we cover
in our acquisitions.
I cover military history and natural history and Eastern European studies and environmental books and natural history books.
And Mary Lynn covers Texas history, Western history, political science and presidential studies and Mexican-American studies and so on.
So we divide up the chores that way.
But we don't go out and try to educate ourselves in military history other than just the normal reading that we've done over the years.
All right.
Now, at first, you did that early reading of that early manuscript.
Then you also did the copy editing.
When I first came to work here, I only did copy editing.
Oh, all right, okay.
Right, but then you move on up.
Yeah, for a while there, I was doing everything.
All right, now the copy editor.
Mary Lynn was, too.
And the copy editor, what does the copy editor look for?
Everything?
Yeah, you look for everything from punctuation mistakes
to the style of presentation and whether the book is going to be the language of the book, the style of the book is going to be understandable to the market at which it's aimed.
Copy editing is an important job, and I'll always respect the people who do it, because it takes a special person to be able to focus on them.
on a book like that.
And the copy editor doesn't have to be a specialist in the field that he or she is working with.
I edited many manuscripts in my time that I had no idea what they were talking about, technically.
I mean, a book in French foreign policy, for example,
I knew who de Gaulle was, and that was about it.
But I could get into the book, and if the author said something that didn't make sense, I at least knew to query it and ask the author, do you really mean this?
It's misleading to me, a layperson.
Will it be clear to other readers?
And I think that's the most important thing a copy editor can add to a book is to
be able to recognize where other readers might stumble.
And you used a blue pencil until about when?
About 87, 88.
Well, no, it was actually later than that.
We started using computers here about 87.
Before that, of course, we used them in the business office, but then the editorial and marketing offices and design and production, we began using computers in the late 80s.
And then we really began starting to get manuscripts on disk in the early 90s, say seven or eight years ago.
And of course now practically every manuscript we get is on disk.
Are there still some that come in?
in the old-fashioned way.
Very, very rarely.
And usually you can spot those in the proposal material that they send.
If it's still typewritten, it's someone who either has an old manuscript that they've dragged out of the closet or someone who doesn't know how to use a computer.
And in a case like that, you wonder if they are up-to-date enough to
to have a manuscript that's worthwhile.
There are some people who are.
What's his name?
Skutch, the ornithologist and natural history man.
I can't think of his first name.
S-K-U-T-C-H, Skutch?
Right, Skutch.
He lives in Costa Rica, and he's very elderly, but he keeps putting out wonderful books on bird life.
And we published two of his books, The Minds of Birds, and Trogon's Falcons, and another bird.
And he still types everything out on a typewriter.
He lives in Costa Rica, way back in the forest.
And he pounds it out on typewriter.
Now, for him, he's published books with many different publishers, and we feel honored and fortunate when we get one of his manuscripts.
So for him, we're willing to have it transcribed to a computer.
As you look back over these 25 years, can you remember one or more that from start to finish, it was a joy to work with, where that one kind of stood out?
What would be some of your favorites?
I'll tell you one that has always stood out in my mind is Lighthouses of Texas.
This is one of the paintings, one of the illustrations from that book.
And that book just clicked into place from start to finish.
I was at the Oklahoma Historical Society meeting
at their centennial meeting in Guthrie, Oklahoma.
And I was so happy to be there, because that was my home state.
And it was the centennial meeting, 100th year after the big land rush.
And one of the speakers there was T. Lindsey Baker, who I'd known for years, Texas historian.
He was speaking to them.
And he and I got together, and we decided to go have a drink
one of the old restored saloons in Guthrie, downtown Guthrie.
And we picked up Jim Steeley along the way.
Jim Steeley's with the Texas Historical Commission.
I'd known Jim for years, too.
And we went to the saloon, and we're sitting around talking, and I asked Lindsey what he was working on.
And he said, well, I've been doing research on the lighthouses of Texas.
And I said, well, that's really interesting because I've always wanted to publish a book on the lighthouses of Texas.
We ought to discuss this more.
And Jim Steele pipes up and he says, well, it really is interesting because the Texas Historical Commission has grant money from the National Park Service to publish a book on Texas lighthouses.
So right there at the table, we all three came up with the project.
Lindsey would write the text, and I would help him put it together and get the illustrations, and Jim would provide the funding.
And I came back to the office and
was walking through the halls and I saw Harold Phoenix's painting, it's in the Wardlaw collection here, his painting of an oil derrick.
I think it's hanging in the director's office right now.
And I thought, you know, that has exactly the proportions of a lighthouse, the derrick standing up there in the middle of an open field.
And so I called Harold and
asked him if he would be interested in doing these lighthouses.
And he was delighted.
And he traveled to every site on the Texas coast, whether the lighthouse was still standing there or not.
He was there in person, even took the boat ride out to the old Sabine Pass lighthouse site.
And then he went through old photographs
did a lot of research before he did these paintings, and they were a wonderful addition to the book, beautiful things.
Now, how many of the originals did we end up with in the press?
Just this one.
And what did he do, sell the others?
He sold the others, yes.
Well, actually, what happened was the Rockport Maritime Museum
wanted to host an autographing.
And so the opening for the book was there in Rockport at the museum.
And then they purchased all of the original paintings except this one.
And so they wanted this one, and he said, well, I've already promised it to the press for the Wardlaw collection.

and so they they commissioned him to paint a replacement for it which is the same lighthouse just uh you know it's a little bit different and so he said well while he was doing that he just painted a whole new series and sold those for his for himself a trivia from my mandel rogers
Is he still doing Texas art?
Yes, he's still working in Sweetwater, still painting.
Because there used to be a place in downtown Lubbock upstairs of what I'd call a big

office supply place and when you were opening up and say you're opening up a new office they've got all the chairs and the tables and the desk everything but also they had art and we used to stop and some of his art would be there but the last few times we haven't seen it there but he's still active uh the last i heard he was i talked to someone
From Sweetwater, it's been less than a year ago.
So you'll be back out there.
All right, back to manuscripts.
Can you think of a manuscript or so, the wording, the written manuscript, that was marvelous for its quality and lacked little need of editing?
Are there any you recall that were?
oh, I remember one, and that's one of those that got away, too.
